text.headline: The History of Machine Learning (1943 - 2025)
text.text: Machine learning is a subfield of Artificial Intelligence that...

media.caption: Photo of Walter Pitts and Warren McCulloch

text.headline: First Mathematical Model of Neural Networks
text.text: The concept of machine learning begins with Walter Pitts and Warren McCulloch's scientific paper entitled "A logical calculus of the ideas immanent in nervous activity". This paper became a cornerstone in the development of neural networks and artificial intelligence, that also presented a mathematical concept of neural networks.

text.headline: The Turing Test
text.text: "Can machines think?", Alan Turing, the creator of the Turing Test asked in his paper "Computing Machinery and Intelligence ". This paper presented how to determine the real intelligence of machines, giving birth to the Turing Test. The Turing Test is a test which the machine can only pass if it was able to imitate a real human, fooling the real human called judge that it is conversing with.

media.caption: Frank Rosenblatt ’50, Ph.D. ’56, works on the “electronic profile analyzing computer” – a precursor to the perceptron.

text.headline: The Perceptron
text.text: In 1957, Frank Rosenblatt combined Hebb’s neural theory with Arthur Samuel’s machine learning work to create the perceptron, originally designed as software for the IBM 704 and installed in the custom-built Mark I perceptron machine for image recognition. Though hailed as the first successful neuro-computer, the Mark I fell short in recognizing complex patterns like faces, leading to disillusionment and a decline in neural network research. This setback stalled progress until a resurgence of interest in the 1990s revived machine learning efforts.

text.headline: The Nearest Neighbor Algorithm
text.text: In 1967, the nearest neighbor algorithm was introduced, marking a key step in early pattern recognition and route mapping. It was one of the first methods used to tackle the traveling salesperson problem by having the program visit the closest unvisited city at each step. While Marcello Pelillo is credited with the "nearest neighbor rule," he attributes its origins to the influential 1967 paper by Cover and Hart.

text.headline: Explanation-Based Learning
text.text: Gerald Dejong introduced the concept of Explanation Based Learning (EBL), where a computer analyses training data and creates a general rule it can follow by discarding unimportant data.

media.credit: A Brief History to Machine Learning by Dataversity.net

text.headline: Shift to a Data-Driven Approach
text.text: In the 1990s work on machine learning shifted from a knowledge-driven approach to a data-driven approach.  Scientists began creating programs for computers to analyze large amounts of data and draw conclusions — or “learn” — from the results.

media.caption: World Chess Champion Garry Kasparov (L) makes a move during his fourth game against the IBM Deep Blue chess computer.
media.credit: A Brief History to Machine Learning by Dataversity.net

text.headline: AI Beating a World Champion in Chess
text.text: A historic event that makes AI known in the world - IBM's Deep Blue defeat's world chess champion Garry Kasparov in chess.

text.headline: Being Bobby Brown
text.text: Being Bobby Brown was a reality show starring Brown and wife Whitney Houston. Houston refused to sign for a second season. A clip of her telling Brown to "Kiss my ass," became a running gag on The Soup.

text.headline: A Rocky Comeback
text.text: Houston's comeback tour is cut short due to a diminished voice damaged by years of smoking. She was reportedly devastated at her inability to perform like her old self.

media.caption: Houston, performing on Good Morning America in 2009.

text.headline:
Whitney Houston
1963-2012
text.text: Houston, 48, was discovered dead at the Beverly Hilton Hotel on on Feb. 11, 2012. She is survived by her daughter, Bobbi Kristina Brown, and mother, Cissy Houston.
